de.frauas.jdemandmodel.lighting

Class Lighting

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.frauas.jdemandmodel.lighting.Lighting

  • public class Lighting
extends java.lang.Object
    The class Lighting can be used to simulate the lighting of a dwelling for 1440 1-minute time intervals of a day. The only data that need to be provided is the occupancy of the dwelling (OccupancyModeler). Also, an optional bulb configuration can be set by choosing a house number between 1 and 100 (representing 100 sample households). Choosing -1 will result in a random configuration and 0 turns the light off (returns array of length 1440 filled with zeros).

    The content is a direct translation of the "RunLightingSimulation" macro of the Domestic Lighting Demand Model (2008) by I. Richardson and M. Thomson from Loughborough University (http://hdl.handle.net/2134/4065).

    Author:
    lukas

    • Constructor Detail

      • Lighting

        public Lighting(int[] activeOccupancy)
        Creates new Lighting. All necessary files are read in in the constructor.
        Parameters:
        activeOccupancy - the active occupancy values to be used for simulating the lighting demand of a dwelling
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the length of the passed array does not equal 1440

    • Method Detail

      • setHouseNumber

        public void setHouseNumber(int houseNumber)
        This is for deciding which house (bulb configuration) should be used when simulating light. Passing -1 will result in a random configuration while 1 turns the light off ("getLightingValues" will return an array of zeros).
        Parameters:
        houseNumber - the number of the house and corresponding bulb configuration to be used for simulation
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the passed number is less than -1 or grater than 100

      • getLightingValues

        public int[] getLightingValues()
        The main iteration goes through all bulbs that have been chosen (house number). Then, it is iterated for each bulb through time, at each minute deciding whether a switch-on event should happen using e.g. time of day (irradiance) and effective occupancy as input. See https://dspace.lboro.ac.uk/2134/4759 for further detail. If a bulb is switched on, next, the duration of the event is calculated and the power value of the current bulb added to the final result.
        Returns:
        1440 power values [W] representing the lighting demand of a dwelling.

      • getBulbArray

        private int[] getBulbArray()
        Returns:
        the bulb array that corresponds to the currently specified house number.

      • getBulbArrays

        private java.util.ArrayList<int[]> getBulbArrays()
        Reads in all bulb arrays using a CSVReader.
        Returns:
        an array list containing all bulb arrays from the file "input/lighting/bulbs.csv".

      • getIrradianceArray

        private int[] getIrradianceArray()
        Reads in the irradiance for the currently specified month using a CSVReader.
        Returns:
        the irradiance array from the file "input/lighting/irrandiance.csv" for the current month.

      • determineDuration

        private int determineDuration()
        Method to terminate the duration of a bulb staying turned on. For further detail see https://dspace.lboro.ac.uk/2134/4759.
        Returns:
        and integer representing the time [min] a bulb should be turned on for.
